Come up with graphs, charts, anaylsis, and include qualitative and quantitative ways to describe the applicants to our newest program at Bloom.pm a social enterprise startup accelerator

review these teams and come up with some interesting ways to represent the data
 : GRADE A PLUS in ACSI4	Jocelyne Saade	jocelyne.j.saade@gmail.com	GRADE A PLUS	Personally and professionally, I'm driven by the urgent need to address both environmental challenges and economic hardship in Lebanon, particularly in the Aarsal region. The provided data demonstrates the significant economic and agricultural potential of our SoilPlus product. Seeing how we can transform discarded sheep wool into a valuable resource that not only improves crop yields (as shown by the 293% ROI with SoilPlus) but also significantly reduces costs for farmers compared to traditional methods (as evidenced by the lower total costs), is incredibly motivating. I'm passionate about creating sustainable solutions that empower local communities and contribute to a more resilient future. The ACSI4 program offers a unique opportunity to scale our impact and bring these benefits to more farmers who desperately need them	I play a key role in leading business development and funding initiatives at Grade A Plus. With a background as a mechanical engineer and a master’s degree in renewable energy, I bring a strong technical foundation to our team, ensuring that our solutions align with sustainable and innovative practices.   My expertise lies in research, development, and procurement, enabling me to identify opportunities that drive the company’s growth. I actively represent Grade A Plus in funding programs, exhibitions, and collaborative ventures, forging strategic partnerships that expand our reach. My deep understanding of funding mechanisms allows me to secure financial support essential for scaling our impact.   Beyond my technical knowledge, I excel in networking and market analysis, ensuring that our strategies align with industry trends. My passion for sustainability drives me to create and promote eco-friendly solutions, contributing to the long-term vision of Grade A Plus. Through my skills and dedication, I strive to position our company as a leader in sustainable agriculture and environmental innovation.	https://www.linkedin.com/company/98223191/admin/dashboard/	Female	35-39	Lebanon	Lebanon	(961) 301-7955	2022-06-30	Lebanon	Yes	Agriculture; General / Other	SDG GOAL 1: No Poverty:::SDG GOAL 3: Good Health and Well-being:::SDG GOAL 9: Industry / Innovation / Infrastructure:::SDG GOAL 13: Climate Action:::SDG GOAL 15: Life on Land:::SDG GOAL 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth	Our initiative aspires to make a substantial impact, primarily aligned with SDG 15: Life on Land. We aim to address key targets within this goal, promoting sustainable land use and biodiversity conservation. Our quantifiable impact metrics include: 1. Land Restoration: Through partnerships with organizations like the Lebanon Reforestation Initiative (LRI) NGO, we conducted experiments on 120 trees planted in December 2023, contributing to Target 15.3 (land degradation neutrality). Future collaborations, such as the upcoming pilot project with GreenLeb in March 2024, further this goal. 2. Biodiversity Enhancement: We seek to boost biodiversity by promoting natural fertilizers. Target 15.9, emphasizing the integration of ecosystems and biodiversity into planning, guides our efforts, with a targeted 20% increase in the diversity of flora and fauna where our pellets are applied. 3. Water Conservation: Anticipating a 25% reduction in water consumption for irrigation, our pellets, by reducing the need for chemical fertilizers and enhancing soil water retention, contribute to sustainable agricultural practices. 4. Economic Empowerment: Contributing to SDG 1 and SDG 8, our initiative creates income streams for shepherds and generates jobs. We currently empower eight families in our workshop and 15 shepherd families annually. As our business expands, we aim to uplift more families out of poverty. 5. Carbon Emission Reduction: While indirectly linked to SDG 15, our efforts reduce the burning of sheep wool and the carbon footprint in agriculture, contributing to SDG 13. Over our three working years, we have successfully reduced 200 tons of CO2 emissions.Through these quantifiable goals, we envision a holistic impact aligned with SDG 15 and intersecting with other critical sustainability objectives.	Entrepreneurship:::Tech & Innovation	"4.2. Revenues are stagnant or growing slowly, but the enterprise is not however profitable/sustainable"	5	Yes	Increasing	Yes	No	www.gradeaplus.net facebook : SoilPlusLeb Instagram: soilplus_lebanon	https://www.canva.com/design/DAGf6YhTD3A/oH9ThCRcFWBXR35lgNtYBA/edit?utm_content=DAGf6YhTD3A&utm_campaign=designshare&utm_medium=link2&utm_source=sharebutton	Lebanon generates 2,500 tons of sheep wool waste annually, a significant environmental burden that we at GRADE A PLUS are determined to transform. Simultaneously, Lebanese farmers, particularly in regions like Aarsal, face severe economic challenges due to high input costs. Our data, for example, shows conventional fertilizer costing $278.5 per 320m², hindering profitability. We identified this dual problem through direct observation of both the pervasive waste and the struggles of local farmers. Our data analysis, demonstrating SoilPlus's ability to significantly reduce costs and increase profits (with a 293% ROI), confirmed the viability of our upcycling solution. This provides a sustainable and economically beneficial alternative, turning a waste problem into a resource for struggling farmers.	Our Startup: GRADE A PLUS GRADE A PLUS is a Lebanese startup dedicated to transforming environmental challenges into sustainable economic opportunities. We address the pressing issue of sheep wool waste, of which Lebanon generates 2,500 tons annually, by upcycling it into high-value agricultural and other sustainable products. Recognizing the economic hardships faced by Lebanese farmers, particularly in regions like Aarsal, we've developed innovative solutions that not only mitigate waste but also enhance agricultural productivity and profitability. Our Solution: SoilPlus and SoilPlus Pro Our flagship products, SoilPlus and SoilPlus Pro, are soil enhancers made from 100% upcycled sheep wool. They offer a sustainable alternative to conventional fertilizers, addressing both environmental and economic concerns. •	SoilPlus: As shown in the provided data, SoilPlus demonstrates exceptional cost-effectiveness. With a total cost of $194.8 per 320m², it significantly reduces input costs for farmers compared to conventional 20-20-20 fertilizer, which costs $278.5. Moreover, despite a lower initial investment, SoilPlus delivers the highest profit ($570.7) and a remarkable 293% return on investment (ROI), primarily attributed to the higher selling price per kg ($0.8) of the produce grown with it. •	SoilPlus Pro: While slightly more costly at $221.6 per 320m², SoilPlus Pro also offers a cost-effective solution compared to conventional fertilizers. It delivers a substantial yield (1255.25 kg) and a profit of $280.5, representing a 127% ROI. Key Benefits: •	Cost Reduction: Both SoilPlus and SoilPlus Pro significantly reduce input costs for farmers compared to conventional fertilizers. •	Increased Profitability: SoilPlus, in particular, demonstrates a significantly higher profit margin and ROI. •	Sustainable Agriculture: By upcycling sheep wool, we reduce waste and promote environmentally friendly farming practices. •	Improved Soil Health: Our products enhance soil structure and water retention, leading to healthier crops. •	Local Economic Development: We support Lebanese farmers and contribute to the economic resilience of rural communities. Our Vision: We envision a future where waste is transformed into valuable resources, and sustainable agriculture empowers Lebanese farmers. GRADE A PLUS is committed to leading this transformation by providing innovative, eco-friendly solutions that benefit both people and the planet. This funding is essential for supporting our sales and marketing efforts, enabling us to reach more farmers, distributors, and key stakeholders. By securing this support, we will be able to strengthen our market presence, increase product awareness, and generate the necessary revenue to sustain and grow our operations. Investing in sales and marketing at this stage will not only help us overcome current economic difficulties but will also ensure long-term financial stability for the company, allowing us to continue delivering innovative, sustainable solutions to the agricultural sector. SyrConn in ACSI4	Yaser Dalal	yasser.ply@gmail.com	SyrConn	From a personal perspective, what motivates me about SyrConn is its impact-driven mission—empowering Syrian professionals by providing them with access to global opportunities, financial security, and a pathway to professional growth. The idea of bridging talent with demand in a way that removes barriers is truly inspiring.  From a professional standpoint, the challenge of building a scalable, secure, and sustainable freelance marketplace is highly motivating. The opportunity to create a unique business model tailored to Syria's economic and regulatory landscape, while leveraging technology to solve real-world problems, is an exciting prospect.	As the Founder and CEO of SyrConn, my main role is to set the vision, strategy, and direction of the platform while ensuring its successful execution. I drive business growth, build partnerships, oversee operations, and lead the team toward achieving SyrConn’s mission.  My key strengths include:  - Strategic Leadership: Setting a clear roadmap and making high-impact decisions. - Problem-Solving: Overcoming challenges in the Syrian freelance market with innovative solutions. - Networking & Partnerships: Building relationships with investors, clients, and stakeholders. - Entrepreneurial Mindset: Driving SyrConn from concept to execution with persistence and adaptability. - Passion for Impact: A deep commitment to empowering Syrian professionals and creating real opportunities.	https://www.linkedin.com/in/yaser-dalal-a78538b8/	Male	35-39	Syria	Syria	963949998094	2024-01-02	Syria	No	Financial Services; General / Other	SDG GOAL 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth:::SDG GOAL 17: Partnerships to achieve the Goal:::SDG GOAL 1: No Poverty:::SDG GOAL 9: Industry / Innovation / Infrastructure:::SDG GOAL 10: Reduced Inequality	Through SyrConn, I aspire to create a transformational impact by empowering Syrian professionals and freelancers, bridging global job opportunities, and fostering economic growth. This impact aligns directly with several United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs):  1. SDG 8: Decent Work & Economic Growth Job Creation: Enable 10,000+ Syrian freelancers to access remote work opportunities within the first 3 years. Income Generation: Increase the average freelancer income by 50-100% compared to local employment. Economic Inclusion: Provide secure, cross-border income without reliance on traditional banking restrictions. 2. SDG 1: No Poverty Financial Stability: Ensure at least 70% of freelancers on SyrConn secure consistent monthly income within their first 6 months. Reducing Unemployment: Support fresh graduates and displaced professionals by connecting them with sustainable income sources. 3. SDG 9: Industry, Innovation & Infrastructure Digital Transformation: Build a fully operational digital marketplace that processes at least $1 million in transactions by Year 3. Capacity Building: Offer training programs to enhance freelancers' skills, ensuring 90% job completion rates and high client satisfaction. 4. SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities Global Access: Connect Syrian talent with 100+ international businesses and NGOs in the first 2 years. Equal Opportunity: Provide women and marginalized groups with equal access to freelancing opportunities, targeting at least 40% female participation. 5. SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals Strategic Collaborations: Partner with at least 10 global organizations, NGOs, and business incubators to expand reach and support freelancers. Policy Advocacy: Work with local and international stakeholders to promote fair digital work policies for Syrians. Measurable Long-Term Impact: 50,000+ registered freelancers on SyrConn within 5 years. $10+ million in earnings processed through the platform by Year 5. 75%+ freelancer retention rate due to stable work opportunities and payment security. By breaking financial and logistical barriers, SyrConn will redefine freelancing for Syrian professionals, drive economic independence, and create a sustainable future for thousands.	Active citizenship & civic engagement:::Entrepreneurship	"2.1. Exploring ideas, conducting market/customer research"	2	No	No sales yet	No	No	N/A	NA	Problem Statement: Syrian professionals, freelancers, and fresh graduates face significant barriers in accessing job opportunities, both locally and internationally. These challenges include:  Lack of Job Opportunities – Many skilled individuals struggle to find work that matches their expertise. Limited Global Connections – Syrian freelancers often lack direct access to international clients and businesses. Payment & Financial Restrictions – Due to banking sanctions, most international payment platforms (e.g., PayPal) are inaccessible, making it difficult for freelancers to receive payments securely. Trust & Quality Concerns – Clients hesitate to hire freelancers due to uncertainties about work quality and payment security. How I Identified the Problem: As a professional deeply involved in business and economic challenges in Syria, I noticed that many highly skilled Syrians were struggling to find work despite their talent. Conversations with freelancers, students, and professionals highlighted the same recurring issues: a lack of access to jobs, difficulty in receiving payments, and a lack of trust between service providers and clients.  Through market research and discussions with both service seekers and providers, it became clear that SyrConn could bridge this gap by creating a secure, structured digital marketplace where Syrian professionals could connect with global clients while ensuring safe transactions and quality work delivery	Startup Overview: SyrConn – Connecting Syrian Creators with the World SyrConn is a digital freelance marketplace designed to empower Syrian professionals, freelancers, and students by connecting them with global job opportunities in a secure and structured environment. The platform enables service providers—such as developers, designers, engineers, writers, and marketers—to offer their skills to international clients without financial or logistical barriers.  Solution: How SyrConn Solves the Problem SyrConn directly addresses the challenges faced by Syrian freelancers by offering:  A Digital Job Marketplace – A specialized online platform where Syrian professionals can showcase their skills and connect with businesses worldwide. Secure Payment Processing – A built-in escrow system that ensures freelancers receive their earnings without needing external banking solutions like PayPal. Quality Assurance & Trust – A review and rating system backed by industry professionals to ensure high-quality service delivery. International Access & Opportunities – Direct connections to global businesses, startups, and NGOs seeking skilled professionals at competitive rates. Scalable Revenue Model – SyrConn generates revenue through a 15% commission on transactions and premium memberships for enhanced visibility and job access. By removing financial restrictions, ensuring job security, and creating a reliable ecosystem, SyrConn empowers Syrian professionals to thrive in the global digital economy—unlocking new economic opportunities for thousands. Have an early (low-fidelity/paper) prototype (of product or service)	3	No	No sales yet	No	No	N/A	https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-SSKCaWbgXqk6tmjizPl019IEARCCwuP/view?usp=drive_link	The problem we are solving is the rapid spread of climate change misinformation, which leads to public confusion, delays in policy action, and resistance to sustainable practices. False claims such as “Climate change is a hoax” or “CO₂ is not harmful” mislead millions, especially in regions with limited fact-checking resources.    We first identified this problem through social media analysis and discussions with climate experts, we found that in Arabic-speaking communities there is lack in real-time, and AI-driven fact-checking tools, leads to an information gap.  While seeing the impact of misinformation on public opinion and policy-making, we recognized the urgent need for a scalable, AI-driven fact-checking solution that works seamlessly in multiple languages.	Our startup is an AI-powered bilingual chatbot designed to combat climate change misinformation in English and Arabic. It provides real-time fact-checking by leveraging AI, verified climate data, and APIs from Google Fact Check, NASA, and IPCC. The chatbot is accessible via a web platforms, making accurate climate information available to the public, policymakers, journalists, and educators.   Our solution automates misinformation detection, educates users with scientifically backed responses, and bridges the language gap in climate communication. واستراتيجيات التنمية الزراعية:  الحكومة والمنظمات الدولية تدعم تقنيات الحفاظ على المياه، لكن الحلول الحالية مثل التحلية أو الري الذكي مكلفة جدًا أو غير مناسبة للزراعة واسعة النطاق.     كيف يحل الطين الصناعي المشكلة؟  يقلل استهلاك المياه بنسبة 40-60% عبر تحسين قدرة التربة على الاحتفاظ بالرطوبة.  يزيد إنتاجية المحاصيل بنسبة 30-50% من خلال توفير بيئة زراعية أكثر استقرارًا.  يخفض تكاليف الزراعة بنسبة 20-35%، مما يجعلها أكثر جدوى للمزارعين المحليين.  يساعد في إعادة تأهيل الأراضي الصحراوية، مما يساهم في إبطاء التصحر وتحقيق الأمن الغذائي. 	وصف المشروع الناشئ  مشروعي هو "الطين الصناعي للزراعة في الصحراء"، وهو حل مبتكر لمواجهة تحديات الزراعة في المناطق الجافة مثل المفرق. يعتمد المشروع على تطوير مادة طينية صناعية صديقة للبيئة، تُضاف إلى التربة لتحسين قدرتها على الاحتفاظ بالمياه والمواد المغذية، مما يساعد في زراعة المحاصيل بكفاءة أعلى وباستهلاك مياه أقل.  الحل الذي يقدمه المشروع  1. تقليل استهلاك المياه في الزراعة  بفضل قدرة الطين الصناعي على الاحتفاظ بالرطوبة، يمكن تقليل الحاجة إلى الري بنسبة 40-60%، مما يجعل الزراعة أكثر استدامة في المناطق القاحلة.    2. زيادة إنتاجية المحاصيل  يحسن الطين الصناعي من هيكل التربة، مما يسمح للجذور بالاستفادة من المياه والعناصر الغذائية بفعالية، ما يؤدي إلى زيادة الإنتاج الزراعي بنسبة 30-50%.    3. خفض تكاليف الزراعة  تقليل الحاجة إلى الأسمدة والري المتكرر يؤدي إلى خفض التكاليف التشغيلية بنسبة 20-35%، مما يجعل الزراعة أكثر جدوى اقتصاديًا للمزارعين.    4. إعادة تأهيل الأراضي الصحراوية  يمكن استخدام الطين الصناعي في تحويل الأراضي المتدهورة إلى أراضٍ زراعية قابلة للإنتاج، مما يساعد في مكافحة التصحر وزيادة المساحات الخضراء.    5. منتج صديق للبيئة ومستدام  الطين الصناعي مصنوع من مواد طبيعية وقابلة للتحلل، مما يجعله بديلاً مستدامًا للأسمدة الكيميائية وحلاً بيئيًا طويل الأمد.     لماذا هذا الحل مبتكر؟  يعتمد على تقنية منخفضة التكلفة وسهلة التطبيق مقارنة بالحلول الأخرى مثل تحلية المياه أو أنظمة الري الذكي.  يستهدف المناطق القاحلة التي تعاني من ندرة المياه، مما يجعله حلاً عمليًا للمجتمعات الزراعية في الأردن وخارجه. Coastal Clean Up in ACSI4	Mary Kalunde Munyao	marlenemunyao@gmail.com	Coastal Clean Up	At the moment, I am deeply motivated both personally and professionally by the urgent need to create scalable, technology-driven solutions for environmental sustainability.  I have witnessed firsthand the challenges waste collectors and manufacturers face in the plastic recycling value chain. Professionally, I am driven by the opportunity to leverage digital solutions to create economic opportunities for waste collectors while reducing plastic pollution. Personally, my passion for environmental conservation and social equity fuels my commitment to making coastal communities cleaner and more sustainable. The chance to bring innovation to this space excites me, as I believe technology can bridge existing gaps and create an inclusive, transparent, and profitable recycling ecosystem.	As a Co-Founder of Coastal Clean Up, my main role is leading strategic development, partnerships, and operational execution. I focus on ensuring that our model is both impactful and scalable by integrating innovative approaches to plastic waste management. My strengths lie in program management, business development, and stakeholder engagement. I bring experience in designing and implementing sustainability initiatives, leveraging technology for social impact, and building strategic collaborations with manufacturers, waste collectors, and policymakers. Also, my background in gender empowerment ensures inclusivity in our approach, creating opportunities for underserved communities, particularly women in waste collection and recycling. Have started developing my idea	4	No	No sales yet	No	No	N/A	https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1j7Jg_YCWoEs6yZ8oAr9Iih3C5s2yKyoa/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=109267772013789404405&rtpof=true&sd=true	Plastic pollution is a critical environmental challenge, particularly in coastal areas, where improperly managed plastic waste contaminates marine ecosystems, disrupts livelihoods, and contributes to climate change. Many waste collectors lack direct access to buyers, resulting in low earnings, inefficiencies in recycling, and a disconnect between waste sources and manufacturers. During our involvement in coastal clean-up initiatives, we observed massive plastic accumulation along shorelines and waterways. Conversations with local waste pickers and community members revealed key challenges: Limited market access: Collectors struggle to find consistent buyers, often relying on middlemen who offer low prices. Lack of fair compensation: Manual collection is labor-intensive, yet collectors earn little due to pricing inefficiencies. Inefficient recycling systems: Manufacturers face difficulties sourcing high-quality, sorted recyclables. This gap between waste collection and recycling markets led us to develop a tech-enabled solution—a digital waste marketplace that connects collectors directly to buyers, ensuring fair pay, efficient transactions, and increased plastic recycling rates.	Our startup, Coastal Clean Up, is a tech-driven circular economy venture that focuses on tackling plastic pollution in coastal regions. We empower waste collectors by providing direct access to buyers (manufacturers & recyclers) through a digital waste marketplace. Solution: We have developed a mobile app that enables: Digital Waste Tracking – Waste collectors can log their plastic collections, receive digital receipts, and track earnings. Instant Payments – Secure mobile money transactions ensure real-time payouts for waste collected. Marketplace Feature – Connects waste collectors directly with manufacturers and recyclers, eliminating middlemen and ensuring fair prices. ADADK in ACSI4	Bayan Al-Abdullat	alabdullat.b@gmail.com	ADADK	The two founders of Adadk belong to indigenous communities in Jordan, and they met at the Green and Climate Change Hackathon in Germany. They noticed that many homes and farms in rural areas had water leaks and contamination problems, and they spent a lot of money trying to find the leaks and/or contamination and solve them. However, this offline approach failed because there were no smart online solution systems available to quickly locate leaks, define the type of contamination, and alert users to any unusual usage.   Moreover, the same thing happened when they were staying at different buildings and hotels in urban areas in the Middle East and Africa for events and learned there was a problem with water leaks; those hotels forced them to move to another floor because they needed to perform urgent maintenance due to the damage caused by the leaks; it was noisy, and they were very unhappy about it. Also, there was a significant water loss that increased the cost of the bill. These challenges inspired us to develop long-lasting technologies.	Founders: 1. Bayan Al-Abdullat (Founder & CEO), Electrical Engineer: IoT and AI Development, and Data Analysis (+15 years of experience) 2. Najwan Mohammad (CFO), Climate Finance Manager: Financial and Climate Impact Analysis (+8 years of experience).  Bayan Al-Abdullat has a degree in Electrical Engineer and MBA from the University of Connecticut, and he is a Halcyon Fellow, a Royal Academy of Engineering Fellow, UN, and the founder of ADADK, which speaks water language by developing smart and affordable technologies that allow us to listen and understand our water and provide people with easy tools to allow every one of us to take real-time action to save our homes, communities, industries, and planet and to promote global water access and reduce water losses for the millions of farmers, households, and refugees who do not have access to clean water.   Co-founders backed by a strong and expert team of engineers, having electronics and IT expertise in the water and agriculture industries. Adadk has 12 full-time employees (70% female, 30% male), and it was co-founded by a woman. In Lebanon, families have long struggled to find reliable workers for house-based services. For decades, many turned to immigrant workers for full-time assistance or hired freelancers after intensive reference checks. However, the economic crisis of 2020, followed by subsequent hardships, including a recent war, has drastically reshaped this market. Many foreign workers have left the country, and unemployment among the local workforce has skyrocketed. Poor Lebanese families and refugees, especially those with no professional skills, are struggling to survive and are at high risk of being exploited or mistreated.	Home Heroes lb tackles the problem by matching families in need of house-based services with workers seeking jobs. Our innovative platform will use AI algorithms to connect unskilled Lebanese citizens and refugees with families, creating job opportunities for those who would otherwise struggle to find employment.  We will ensure that workers, referred to as "Heroes," are placed in fair and respectful working environments, protecting their dignity and providing them with the financial stability they need to support their families. By promoting the value of house-based services, the project also works to change societal perceptions and remove the stigma around this type of work.  For families, Home Heroes lb provides a reliable and affordable solution for their household needs. This not only alleviates the difficulty of finding trusted help but also ensures that the services are accessible to low- and middle-income households. You said: read all the details on bloom ACSI4 - Asfari Challenge for Social Innovation  Thought for a second Below is a comprehensive summary of the details for the Asfari Challenge for Social Innovation (ACSI4) as presented on Bloom:  Overview ACSI4 is the 4th edition of the Asfari Challenge for Social Innovation, designed to support early-stage social enterprises from Lebanon, Jordan, Palestine, and the Syrian diaspora. The program aims to empower changemakers facing crises by providing them with the resources to develop impactful, sustainable solutions for their communities.  BLOOM.PM  Key Program Features Funding: Receive seed funding of up to $3,830 to help develop and scale your social enterprise.  Training & Mentorship: Engage in weekly training sessions, hands-on mentorship, and expert-led workshops that cover key topics like pitching, business model refinement, and resilience-building.  Networking Opportunities: Build connections with mentors, peers, investors, and ecosystem partners. Demo Day provides a platform to showcase your venture to potential funders and collaborators.  Trauma-Informed Support: In recognition of the challenging environments many participants face, the program offers tailored support addressing wellbeing and resilience.  BLOOM.PM  Program Structure Community of Practice:  Connect with social innovators across the region. Participate in expert-led discussions, resource sharing, and collaborative problem-solving. Bootcamp (March–April 2025):  Intensive two-week phase for shortlisted enterprises. Focus on refining pitches, improving prototypes, and strengthening business models. Culminates with a Bootcamp Demo Day. Accelerator (April–August 2025):  For teams that graduate from Bootcamp. Offers deeper training, dedicated mentorship, and further seed funding. Concludes with a final Demo Day to pitch to investors and partners.  BLOOM.PM Open House Sessions Before the application deadline, three virtual Open House sessions will be held:  February 13, 2025 (5:00–6:30 PM GMT+2): Fuel Your Personal & Startup Growth Speakers: Dara Mouracade, David Munir Nabti  February 18, 2025 (5:00–6:30 PM GMT+2): Accelerate Your Social Impact Enterprise in a Day Speaker: David Munir Nabti  February 20, 2025 (4:00–5:30 PM GMT+2): Resilience in Action — Tools for Growth and Renewal Speakers: Fadi El Halabi, Mirna Abi Aad Abi Nassif  Participants will receive calendar invites and have the opportunity to ask questions and network with the program team.  BLOOM.PM  Eligibility & Focus Themes Who Should Apply:  Target Participants: Idea-stage and prototype-stage social enterprises with at least two active team members. Focus Areas: Sustainability, good governance, independent media, active citizenship, lifelong learning, innovation, and systems change. Geographical Focus: Applicants must be based in Lebanon, Jordan, Palestine, or be part of the Syrian diaspora. Note: Single-founder teams or those already engaged in another accelerator (without clear role separation) are not eligible.  BLOOM.PM Timeline Applications Open: February 3, 2025 Open House Sessions: February 13, 18, & 20, 2025 Application Deadline: February 24, 2025 Bootcamp Notification: March 3, 2025 Bootcamp Begins: March 13, 2025 (2-week intensive) Bootcamp Demo Day: April 3, 2025 Accelerator Selection: April 11, 2025 Accelerator Begins: April 22, 2025 (3-month program) Final Demo Day: August 12, 2025 BLOOM.PM Application Process Eligibility Check: Confirm that your team meets the criteria. Submit Application: Complete the online application via the Bloom Platform between February 3 and February 24, 2025. Selection: A review panel will evaluate applications based on team composition, impact potential, value proposition, and traction. Participation: Selected teams will first attend Bootcamp and, if successful, progress to the Accelerator phase. Additional Information Language: The primary language of the program is English, with support in Arabic and French available through selected mentors/trainers. **Gathering insights**

I’m thinking through how to present data for the Bloom.pm program, spanning teams and applicants. This leads me to analyze and make sense of a large data set, aiming to create data visualizations that clearly highlight key trends and characteristics.

**Enhancing data visualization**

I’m detailing a plan to identify regions, sectors, stages, and SDGs of applicants. Creating charts for each category, and analyzing gender and year of founding, will foster a comprehensive overview.

Below is a step-by-step guide, along with example charts and analyses, that you can use to present both **qualitative** and **quantitative** insights about the many applicants for your Bloom.pm social enterprise startup accelerator (ACSI4). The examples focus on some core comparisons—such as country distribution, gender, SDG focus, and venture stage—but you can adapt them to highlight additional dimensions you find relevant (e.g., sector, founding date, or other criteria). 

---

## 1. Outline the Data Points to Highlight

Given the breadth of information each applicant provided, decide on the “layers” of data you’d like to present in charts and analyses. Typical layers include:

1. **Basic Demographics**  
   - Country (Lebanon, Jordan, Syria, Palestine, or other)  
   - Gender (Female, Male, Mixed team, etc.)  
   - Age range (optional, if relevant or available)

2. **Venture Details**  
   - Sector or focus (e.g., Agriculture, Technology, Health, Education, etc.)  
   - Stage of the venture (Idea stage, prototype, early revenues, or more mature)  
   - SDG alignment (which SDGs do they target?)

3. **Team & Leadership**  
   - Female-led or not  
   - Solo founder vs. team

4. **Impact Goals**  
   - Target beneficiaries (e.g., rural farmers, refugees, women, youth)  
   - Impact metrics (e.g., “serve 100 farmers,” “reduce plastic by 2 tons per month,” etc.)

5. **Traction & Partnerships**  
   - Existing partnerships or previous programs  
   - Mention of revenues or funding to date  

Selecting a handful of categories from the above will allow you to create meaningful charts and short write-ups.

---

## 2. Convert the Applicants’ Text Into a Usable Table

A quick tip is to gather a few key columns (like Applicant Name, Country, Gender, Stage, Sector, SDGs) in a spreadsheet or small table. Below is a **sample** structure (fictional data just for demonstration):

| Applicant / Team            | Country   | Gender  | Stage     | Sector           | SDGs                               | Female-Led? |
|-----------------------------|-----------|---------|----------|------------------|-------------------------------------|------------|
| SafeSyria - Asfari (example)| Syria     | Mixed   | 3.1       | Technology       | Goal 16: Peace / Justice           | No         |
| GoPark                      | Lebanon   | Male    | 3.1       | Tech & Innovation| Goal 11, Goal 13                   | No         |
| Grade A Plus                | Lebanon   | Female  | 5.2       | Agriculture      | Goal 15, 9, 13, etc.               | Yes        |
| … and so on …              | Jordan    | Female  | 2.2       | Renewables       | Goal 6, 12                         | Yes        |

Once you have that structure, you can **count** how many applicants appear in each category.

---

## 3. Generate Key Quantitative Insights

Below are some example metrics you might extract from the table:

1. **Number of Applicants by Country**  
   - Lebanon: X  
   - Jordan: Y  
   - Syria: Z  
   - Palestine: W  
   - Others: K  

2. **Venture Stage Distribution**  
   - Stage 1.1 (Idea/Testing): 10  
   - Stage 2.2 (Started Developing Idea): 5  
   - Stage 3.1 (Prototype with Early Users): 8  
   - Stage 4.2 or 4.3 (Some Revenue but Not Yet Profitable): 12  
   - Stage 5.1 or 5.2 (Profitable / Seeking Scalability): 6  

3. **Sector Breakdown**  
   - Agriculture: A  
   - Education: B  
   - Health / Well-being: C  
   - Technology / Innovation: D  
   - Nonprofit or Civic Engagement: E  
   - Food & Beverage: F  
   - Others: G  

4. **SDGs Most Mentioned**  
   - Goal 4 (Quality Education): 15  
   - Goal 5 (Gender Equality): 20  
   - Goal 8 (Decent Work & Economic Growth): 18  
   - Goal 13 (Climate Action): 10  
   - … etc.  

5. **Female-Led Ventures**  
   - Yes: M  
   - No: N  

These raw counts can feed directly into your visuals.

---

## 4. Create Visual Representations

Below are a few **example charts** with a short explanation of each. (All images below are ASCII placeholders—replace them with real charts you create in Excel, Google Sheets, or any analytics tool.)

### A. Applicants by Country (Bar Chart)

```
|           Number of Applicants by Country
|
| 15  █████████████
| 10  █████████     
|  5  █████   
|  0  ─────────────────────────────────
      Lebanon   Jordan   Syria   Palestine
```

- **What it shows**: The volume of applicants from each country, quickly conveying geographical reach.

### B. Venture Stage Distribution (Pie Chart)

```
          Stage Distribution

              ( 1.1  ) 10%
        ( 2.2 ) 15%
( 3.1 ) 20%            ( 5.x ) 25%
       ( 4.x ) 30%
```

- **What it shows**: The percentage of applicants who are at idea, prototype, early revenue, or profitability stages.

### C. Sector / Theme Focus (Stacked Bar or Column Chart)

```
     Agriculture   ████ 15
     Technology    ███████ 22
     Education     ██████████ 30
     Healthcare    ██ 5
     Food & Bev.   ██ 8
     ...
```

- **What it shows**: The distribution of top sectors or thematic focus among your applicants.

### D. SDG Mentions (Horizontal Bar Chart)

```
Goal 4: Quality Education          █████████ (14)
Goal 5: Gender Equality            █████████████ (18)
Goal 8: Decent Work & Econ Growth  ██████████ (12)
Goal 13: Climate Action            █████ ( 7)
Goal 16: Peace & Justice           ████ ( 5)
...
```

- **What it shows**: Which SDGs are most commonly addressed by your applicants.

### E. Female-Led Ventures (Doughnut Chart)

```
        Female-Led Ventures

     40% YES
     60% NO
```

- **What it shows**: Proportion of ventures that have at least one female founder or are entirely female-led.

---

## 5. Add Qualitative Context

Charts are powerful, but **storytelling** and **key takeaways** bring them to life. For instance:

1. **Regional Insights**  
   - “While Lebanon has the highest number of applicants (35%), we see a rising interest from Jordan (25%) and Syria (20%). This shift could reflect growing entrepreneurship ecosystems in these regions.”

2. **SDG Analysis**  
   - “A large portion (45%) target SDG 5 (Gender Equality), possibly reflecting the surge in women-led initiatives and the focus on women's empowerment across the region.”

3. **Stage Observations**  
   - “Interestingly, 40% of ventures remain at early prototype stage, signifying a robust pipeline of new ideas. Meanwhile, around 20% are profitable but seeking scalability, underscoring the need for follow-on funding.”

4. **Sector Gaps**  
   - “We notice fewer applicants in Healthcare and Renewable Energy, which might be an opportunity for more specialized outreach in future cycles.”

5. **Notable Trends**  
   - “Multiple Lebanese ventures mention tackling the economic crisis head-on, focusing on cost-reduction products or local agriculture solutions.”

---

## 6. Highlight Innovative or Unique Approaches (Qualitative)

Beyond the numbers, you can share mini-profiles of a few interesting applicants:

- **Grade A Plus** (Lebanon): *Upcycles sheep wool into SoilPlus, a sustainable fertilizer. Claims a 293% ROI for farmers in cost reduction and yield improvement.*  
- **SyrConn** (Syria): *A digital freelance marketplace specialized for Syrian professionals lacking global job opportunities, aiming for 10,000 new freelancers in 3 years.*  
- **GoPark** (Lebanon): *An “Airbnb of parking” solution that reduces traffic congestion and emissions. Focuses on optimizing underutilized parking spaces for owners.*

Pick out a handful of especially **impactful** or **creative** solutions and describe them in short, punchy paragraphs or bullet points. This helps your audience see the **human story** behind the data.

---

## 7. Conclude with Macro-Level Observations

Wrap up your analysis by tying the data and stories together. Some sample concluding remarks:

> **“Overall, the 50+ applicants reflect a vibrant ecosystem of social innovation in Lebanon, Jordan, Syria, and Palestine. Nearly half are focusing on pressing environmental and agricultural issues, while a growing portion address challenges in education, public safety, and digital marketplaces. The majority are still pre-profit, which underscores the vital need for accelerator support, mentorship, and funding. As we move into the next stage of ACSI4, these insights guide how we’ll tailor our training, networking, and resource allocation to maximize each venture’s success.”**

---

## 8. Presentation Tips

1. **Balance** text with visuals. Summaries of 2-3 lines under each chart let your audience interpret data quickly.
2. **Highlight** big wins or unusual stats in bold or separate callouts.
3. **Allow** time for Q&A and discussion so stakeholders can dive deeper into the insights that matter most.
4. **Use real quotes** from the participants (with permission) to add authenticity to your presentation.
5. **Emphasize your next steps**—e.g., “We’ll focus our next outreach on bridging the gap in Healthcare solutions,” or “We’ll design new programs specifically for female founders at early prototype stage.”

---

# Putting It All Together

By combining **quantitative charts** (country distribution, sector breakdown, SDGs) with **qualitative takeaways** (unique innovation stories, macro-level trends), you’ll give a well-rounded view of the applicant pool. This approach not only engages your audience visually but also ensures the data **tells a story**—one that can guide strategic decisions and galvanize support for your newest Bloom.pm accelerator cohort.

Feel free to adapt these examples to your exact numbers and the real distribution gleaned from your applicant data. Good luck with your presentation, and we hope these suggestions help you deliver insights that are both **compelling** and **actionable**!

SDGs 8 & 9: Economic Growth & Innovation By equipping students with multi-disciplinary thinking and creative problem-solving skills, Beaver Ed prepares them for the future job market and fosters entrepreneurial thinking. SDG 1: No Poverty Through better educational access and skill-building, Beaver Ed indirectly helps break the cycle of poverty by preparing students for higher education and high-value careers in diverse fields, from engineering to the creative industries.  SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities Beaver Ed ensures that high-quality, hands-on learning is accessible to students from diverse backgrounds, reducing the gap in educational opportunities and career pathways.  SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production Designed with sustainability in mind, Beaver Ed uses reusable materials and refill packs, reducing waste and promoting responsible resource consumption.  Beaver Ed aspires to reshape education, preparing students for a world that demands creativity, adaptability, and problem-solving across disciplines. By bridging education with real-world applications, we aim to cultivate a generation of innovators who will drive change, challenge norms, and build a more sustainable and equitable future. Have an early (low-fidelity/paper) prototype (of product or service)	2	No	No sales yet	No	No	Co-Founders Introduction Video: https://youtu.be/Y3xP25pNFtU Prototype Demo: https://youtu.be/82nmQxYEh3g   Co-Founders Linkedin Pages: https://www.linkedin.com/in/jana-barhouche/ https://www.linkedin.com/in/rayan-barhouche-22734559/	https://drive.google.com/file/d/1KyKd8gnQViTidNbhySL8LKE6lL-o0IvL/view?usp=drive_link	Throughout our school years and even in university, we never had the chance to experiment with the theories we learned. Education was structured around memorization, pre-made solutions, and rigid right-or-wrong answers, leaving no room for exploration or discovery. This system was originally designed to produce disciplined factory workers—but in the era of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, it is no longer effective. Also, the lack of hands-on discovery and experimentation can reduce information retention to as low as 5%. This is supported by both the Learning Pyramid and the research of Joyce and Showers, which emphasize the importance of experiential and hands-on learning in increasing information retention to 90%.  Our firsthand experience reinforced this realization. My co-founder, Rayan, founded Bildits, a realistic construction toy integrated into 200+ schools in 5 countries. In 2020, he sold Bildits to a Dubai-based consortium, which is now expanding it into schools across the UAE, KSA, and Europe. I worked at Bildits as an instructor, and together, we saw how hands-on tools transformed the learning experience, making education more engaging, interactive, and effective. One key insight from Bildits was that schools want to innovate but are often hesitant to adopt solutions that add logistical complexity. This inspired us to create Beaver Ed—a hands-on, discovery-based learning tool that seamlessly integrates into classrooms without adding extra workload for teachers or schools.  To validate our idea, we conducted interviews with parents, students, teachers, and school principals:  - Students want more than just theoretical lessons and standardized exams—they want learning to be fun, interactive, and rooted in real-world experiences.  - Parents seek customized learning approaches that recognize their children’s unique strengths. Many feel the traditional system undervalues creativity, social skills, and problem-solving, often harming self-esteem.  - Teachers want their students to excel in official exams but are limited by rigid national curricula. Many try to introduce innovative methods, but these efforts rely on their personal motivation and extra effort.  - School principals aim to advance their institutions but tend to avoid solutions that require significant structural changes or additional workload. Beaver Ed is designed to address the needs of all stakeholders—offering an effortless yet impactful solution that transforms learning into a more engaging, effective, and future-proof experience.  Additionally, the World Economic Forum's report, Schools of the Future: Defining New Models of Education for the Fourth Industrial Revolution, emphasizes the urgent need for educational transformation. Traditional curricula fail to prepare students for the demands of the future workforce. Schools must prioritize creativity, problem-solving, collaboration, and lifelong learning—all of which are at the core of Beaver Ed.	Mixing hands-on and online learning for a better education, Beaver Ed is a construction educational kit designed for schools to help students understand and manually explore the scientific and mathematical concepts they learn in class. The kit aims to promote pure, raw creativity using simple construction materials: wooden bars. Additionally, it provides access to an educational program and a gamified experience that blends real-world applications with digital fun. Our goal is to empower kids to discover and believe in their unique strengths and to guide education towards problem-solving, teamwork, creativity, divergent thinking, and the acceptance of diverse perspectives.  The Beaver physical kit is a hands-on construction tool that includes 50 cm wooden sticks, a safe cutter that allows customizable cuts, and different types of recycled plastic joints for 90-degree and multi-angle connections and rotations. The kit also features a rope for creating mechanisms like cranks, pivoting joints, or even wooden gears, allowing students to construct various structures. We call this 'raw creativity.'    As for schools enrolled in the Beaver Educational Program, each year, the students will receive a kit and participate in monthly challenges via our educational platform. These challenges require students to apply classroom theories in real-world scenarios using our kit. Our curriculum is customized for each school and program, ensuring alignment with their theoretical curriculum. For example, rather than simply drawing a 4 cm line, students might be tasked with connecting two desks by building a bridge. They would measure the distance and cut wooden pieces to the correct length. Challenges start with simple tasks and progress to advanced applications of physics and math concepts. For instance, students may be challenged to construct a crane, considering factors like momentum, range of motion, and weight support.  After each challenge, the Beaver team reviews submissions, providing feedback to students and teachers on both academic and non-graded skills, like creativity, to highlight each student’s unique strengths.    Additionally, we offer a gamified approach to these challenges. In collaboration with online education platforms like Synthesis, which use digital games for learning, Beaver can be integrated into these digital environments. When a character in the game encounters an obstacle, students can construct a physical solution with the Beaver kit, then scan their structure to appear on screen for their character to use. For instance, if the character needs to climb a wall, students build a ladder, scan it, and their character can then climb it. Students can build various structures to assist their character—like bridges, catapults, planes, or boats—blending hands-on creativity with digital learning. Have a functioning (high-fidelity) prototype with early users / early adopters)	-15	Yes	No sales yet	No	No	thegenmovement.com	NA	Gen Z workers face widespread workplace exploitation, from unpaid overtime and unfair contracts to financial instability and lack of legal protection. Many struggle with outdated corporate structures that fail to adapt to modern work expectations, leaving them undervalued, unheard, and unsupported. Freelancers, in particular, often deal with delayed or denied payments with little recourse.   We saw a growing disconnect between Gen Z workers and traditional employers, a frustration echoed in online discussions, workplace complaints, and real-life experiences. Conversations with young professionals highlighted systemic issues: unclear contracts, toxic work environments, and financial struggles. This wasn’t just a trend, it was a crisis. GEN was born to bridge this gap, advocate for change, and build a support system for the next generation of workers.	GEN is a community-driven initiative dedicated to empowering Gen Z workers by advocating for fair pay, legal protection, and workplace transparency. We recognize that traditional corporate structures often fail to adapt to the evolving expectations of young professionals, leading to exploitation, financial instability, and career stagnation. Our mission is to reshape the future of work by giving Gen Z the tools, resources, and support they need to thrive.  Our Solution GEN tackles these challenges through a multi-faceted approach:  🔹 Legal Protection & Advocacy – We provide access to legal resources, ensuring young workers understand their rights and have the support they need to challenge unfair treatment.  🔹 Financial Transparency & Job Security – We push for clear payment structures, fair wages, and timely compensation, especially for freelancers and gig workers.  🔹 Education & Skill-Building – Our workshops help Gen Z professionals navigate old-school management, upskill for career growth, and transition into leadership roles.  🔹 Community & Networking – We foster a strong support system where members can share experiences, find mentorship, and access job opportunities within ethical, worker-friendly companies.  🔹 Corporate & Manager Training – We educate companies and leadership teams on how to effectively manage, retain, and support Gen Z talent, bridging the generational gap in the workplace. As we discussed potential solutions, and scrolled through wellness initiatives online, we couldn’t shake some questions: Why weren’t these programs working? It had to be accessible, culturally relevant, and deeply rooted in the realities of those it aimed to serve.	EmBody—a model that doesn’t just teach wellness but integrates it into real-world contexts. Our solutions are rooted in scientific research, embodied practices, and systemic change, EmBody is designed to make wellness practical, impactful, and culturally relevant. Its primary goal is to reduce nylon waste, thereby promoting environmental sustainability. The camp will also stimulate the economy by encouraging vertical farming, where crops are cultivated in stacked layers, and transforming these yields into innovative new products. Additionally, social, and cultural theater to foster community engagement and creativity.  Another core aspect of the camp is the production of organic compost through the composting of organic waste. To encourage sustainable waste practices, we require organic waste to be delivered in reusable containers rather than plastic bags. In return, we provide compost to individuals, motivating them to adopt eco-friendly habits by using containers instead of disposable bags.  Beyond its practical applications, the camp will also serve as an educational platform. Key statistics include:  In Jordan, the labor force participation rate for women is just 14%, compared to 62.8% for men in 2023 (World Bank Gender Data). The challenge we’re solving comes in two forms: high-moisture waste, which is difficult to store and spoils quickly, and low-moisture waste, which can be repurposed more easily. For high-moisture waste, we developed an innovative machine that can pack 500 kg of waste per hour, keeping it fresh and usable without high costs. For low-moisture waste, we created a system that formulates it into a full, balanced feed mix, helping farmers lower their costs while maintaining high-quality nutrition for their livestock.
